Sheet1.Unnamed: 4: Gas consumed in `notifyUnsubscribe` is underestimated during tests and is greater than 300,000 without pre-warming
Sheet1.Unnamed: 7: notifyUnsubscribe may exceed the 300k gas limit (Base), causing successful Uniswap V4 unsubscribe while Deli gauge accounting remains, enabling permanent reward dilution.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 8:
Root cause: notifyUnsubscribe may exceed the 300k gas limit (Base), causing successful Uniswap V4 unsubscribe while Deli gauge accounting remains, enabling permanent reward dilution.
Preconditions: notifyUnsubscribe call path can exceed unsubscribeGasLimit due to cold storage reads and heavy accounting work.
Attack path: Positions can be unsubscribed at Uniswap level while still counted in Deli gauges; attackers can keep phantom liquidity to dilute rewards.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 9: Further gas optimization; consider deferring heavy cleanup via pendingUnsubscribe flags and a later cleanup call.

Sheet1.Unnamed: 4: blockace, cergyk
Sheet1.Unnamed: 7: Auto-voters can alter their window vote after an epoch has ended because finalize logic does not properly lock in a voter's choice at epoch close. This lets automated voters change selections post‑epoch and manipulate the finalized outcome.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 8: The finalizeWindowVote mechanism does not enforce immutability of a user's vote once the epoch/window is over. An auto-voter (or any voter using automation) can submit a vote during the epoch, then after observing other votes or market conditions, change the vote in the post‑epoch period before finalization, influencing the computed result. This breaks the intended 'votes are fixed when the window closes' invariant and enables strategic manipulation.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 9: Vote results can be manipulated; WETH allocation among options can be biased.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 11: Freeze staking during finalization or snapshot vote weight (e.g., prior epoch weights).
Sheet1.Unnamed: 28: blockace, cergyk
Sheet1.Unnamed: 29: The finalizeWindowVote mechanism does not enforce immutability of a user's vote once the epoch/window is over. An auto-voter (or any voter using automation) can submit a vote during the epoch, then after observing other votes or market conditions, change the vote in the post‑epoch period before finalization, influencing the computed result. This breaks the intended 'votes are fixed when the window closes' invariant and enables strategic manipulation.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 30: NA
Sheet1.Unnamed: 31: Lock votes at epoch close by preventing updates after the voting window ends (or snapshot votes at close and only finalize from the snapshot). Ensure finalize uses the epoch's closed vote state and rejects post‑epoch modifications.

Sheet1.Unnamed: 8:
Root cause: NA
Preconditions: NA
Attack path: NA
Sheet1.Unnamed: 28: Seller Pays Buyer's Trade Fee in Token Swaps, Leading to Systematic Theft of Funds
Sheet1.Unnamed: 29: The token swap settlement path (_executeTokenSwap and _executeAgainstMatcher) computes a buyer fee on the payment amount, then reduces the payment sent to the seller (netPayment = paymentAmount - tradeFee) while also transferring tradeFee from the buyer to the treasury. This means the buyer pays exactly paymentAmount total, and the seller effectively subsidizes the buyer's fee. This contradicts the JIT minting path where each party pays their own fee as an additional transfer.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 30: Buyer submits a token-swap trade where seller expects paymentAmount. Contract computes tradeFee based on buyer fee rate, transfers tradeFee from buyer to treasury, and transfers only paymentAmount - tradeFee to seller. Repeating trades drains sellers by the fee amount on every swap settlement.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 31: Charge buyer fee as additional transfer; seller receives full payment; align token swap logic with JIT minting.

Sheet1.Unnamed: 4: CRITICAL: Access Control Bypass in Fee Management
Sheet1.Unnamed: 7: Administrative fee/treasury/pause setters use onlyAuthorizedMatcher instead of onlyOwner, letting matchers control system parameters.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 8:
Root cause: NA
Preconditions: NA
Attack path: NA
Sheet1.Unnamed: 28: CRITICAL: Access Control Bypass in Fee Management
Sheet1.Unnamed: 29: MarketController functions setFeeRate, setTreasury, and setGlobalTradingPaused are protected by onlyAuthorizedMatcher. Any authorized matcher can raise fees, redirect treasury, and pause trading globally, which should be restricted to owner/admin governance.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 30: A malicious matcher calls setTreasury to an attacker address and setFeeRate to maximum, then continues matching trades to divert protocol fees; or pauses trading to DoS users.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 31: Use onlyOwner for administrative functions; restrict matchers.

Sheet1.Unnamed: 8:
Root cause: NA

Sheet1.Unnamed: 28: PositionTokens violates one of the MUST rules defined in EIP-1155.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 29: PositionTokens constructor initializes ERC1155 with uri set to empty string and provides no update mechanism. This violates ERC-1155 metadata schema expectations and prevents marketplaces/explorers from resolving token metadata.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 30: Not an attacker-driven exploit; users’ position tokens appear without metadata across third-party interfaces permanently.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 31: Initialize with valid metadata URI or allow admin update function.

Sheet1.Unnamed: 4: Emergency resolver targets wrong epoch
Sheet1.Unnamed: 7: emergencyResolveMarket resolves currentEpoch in time-based markets, which can skip the just-finished epoch and lock claims.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 8:
Root cause: NA
Preconditions: NA
Attack path: NA
Sheet1.Unnamed: 28: Emergency resolver targets wrong epoch
Sheet1.Unnamed: 29: emergencyResolveMarket reads market.getCurrentEpoch(questionId) and forwards it to resolver. In time-based markets, getCurrentEpoch advances immediately when a new window starts. With resolutionTime=0, the market is always 'ready', so emergency resolution can accidentally resolve the new epoch while leaving the previous epoch unresolved, storing the merkle root under the wrong conditionId.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 30: Authorized matcher calls emergencyResolveMarket after an epoch rolls. Controller resolves the now-current epoch with a root meant for previous epoch; epoch 1 condition never gets a root so users can’t claim, and epoch 2 becomes locked to incorrect root.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 31: Add explicit epoch parameter and validate it's <= currentEpoch and (for time-based) < currentEpoch.

Sheet1.Unnamed: 4: Integer division rounding down allows buyers to obtain free position tokens in JIT Minting
Sheet1.Unnamed: 7: For small fillAmount, buyerPayment rounds to zero, letting buyers receive position tokens without locking collateral.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 8:
Root cause: NA
Preconditions: NA
Attack path: NA
Sheet1.Unnamed: 28: Integer division rounding down allows buyers to obtain free position tokens in JIT Minting
Sheet1.Unnamed: 29: In _executeJITMinting, buyerPayment=(fillAmount*price)/10000 can round down to 0 when fillAmount is small. The function still mints fillAmount tokens to the buyer for their outcome while locking zero collateral from buyer and full collateral from seller, enabling free token accumulation via repeated tiny trades.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 30: Attacker repeatedly places small buy orders (fillAmount=1) at prices where buyerPayment=0, receiving outcome tokens while contributing no collateral. Later claims full payouts funded by others’ collateral.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 31: Enforce minimum trade size or use higher-precision accounting / rounding up / require non-zero collateral from both sides.

Sheet1.Unnamed: 4: Lack of Emergency Market Invalidation Mechanism
Sheet1.Unnamed: 7: No mechanism to invalidate/cancel an unresolvable market, potentially locking user collateral indefinitely.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 8:
Root cause: NA
Preconditions: NA
Attack path: NA
Sheet1.Unnamed: 28: Lack of Emergency Market Invalidation Mechanism
Sheet1.Unnamed: 29: Resolution requires a non-zero merkleRoot via MarketResolver.resolveMarketEpoch or emergencyResolveMarket. There is no invalidation flag or cancel path to allow users to redeem collateral when an outcome cannot be determined (e.g., event canceled, oracle failure).
Sheet1.Unnamed: 30: If oracle/emergency resolver cannot provide a valid merkle root, conditionId never resolves and claimWinnings reverts forever, leaving collateral locked.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 31: Add invalidation flag and allow users to burn positions and reclaim collateral when market invalidated.

Sheet1.Unnamed: 4: Asymmetric fee structure allows market participants to get the same outcome for less fee
Sheet1.Unnamed: 7: Trade fee is charged on collateral amount (price-dependent), so economically equivalent paths can incur different fees, reducing protocol revenue and enabling fee-minimizing strategies.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 8:
Root cause: NA
Preconditions: NA
Attack path: NA
Sheet1.Unnamed: 28: Asymmetric fee structure allows market participants to get the same outcome for less fee
Sheet1.Unnamed: 29: In swap-based matching, fee is a percentage of paymentAmount, which depends on price. Because selling one outcome is equivalent to buying the complement outcomes, two paths to the same net exposure can be chosen with different fee bases. When claim fee < trade fee, users can choose the cheaper-fee path to exit/enter positions.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 30: User holding YES at high price exits via buying NO (cheaper collateral amount) plus later redeeming full set, paying lower aggregate fees than directly selling YES; can be profitable when fee differences outweigh costs.
Sheet1.Unnamed: 31: Charge fee based on outcome volume traded or symmetric structure across equivalent positions; consider claim fee interaction.
